dialogue.line: Doctor Bashir. The time is oh five hundred.
Yeah, all right.
Julian.
Yes.
We have to get up.
Are you sure?
It's a big day.
It was a big night. It cleared up a lot of unanswered questions.
Such as?
Such as just how far these spots really go down.
I suppose you'll want to tell Miles.
Why would I want to do that?
Because you tell him everything.
True, but you know what? In this case, I'm going to make an exception.
Good. Oh, we really should get up. We don't want the Defiant leaving without us.
You know, I've never been into battle with someone I've slept with before.
There's a first time for everything.
Now that we're finally together, it'd be such a shame if something happened to one of us.
Let's make a pact. We both come home alive.
You've got yourself a deal.
I'm holding you to that.
Oh, and don't forget Kirayoshi has his checkup at oh nine hundred tomorrow.
I've already confirmed the appointment with Nurse Bandee. One more bite
And don't stay up too late writing that paper on, what those trees are called?
Arfillian Ficus and they're not trees, they're shrubs.
Yeah, well, try to get some sleep. Oh, and
Honey, we'll be fine. Stop worrying.
Right. Molly. Please don't touch that.
I let you play with my toys.
Yeah, but you see, this isn't a toy. This is a model.
Maybe it belongs in a museum then.
I suppose I could give it to Julian.
Sounds good to me. Speaking of Julian. Have you told him about Starfleet's offer yet?
No, not yet.
I knew it.
What's that supposed to mean?
We're not going back to Earth.
Of course we are. Daddy's going to teach at the Academy, when the war's over.
Then why haven't you told Julian?
Out of the mouth of babes.
I'll tell him, you know, when I think he's ready to hear it.
How's that?
Oh, it's doing wonders for my head, but it's my stomach that's bothering me.
Well, if it will help, morning sickness ends after the first trimester.
Oh, that's two more months. I don't think I'm going to make it.
You're going to make it.
Ben? Promise me something. Promise that you'll come home to us.
I promise.
I don't believe it
I said I promise.
No, it's not
Come in.
Hey. I thought I'd walk you to the Defiant.
I'd like that.
How's Kas?
Reports of my death have been exaggerated. But not by much.
Isn't there something she can take to make her feel better?
She doesn't like taking medication unless it's absolutely necessary.
Sounds necessary to me.
Waiting for you to leave only makes me feel worse. If you're going to go, just go.
You're sure I can't get you anything?
Just hurry up and come back home.
Mind if I walk with you, Commander?
Not at all. Captain Sisko informed me that you would be joining us on the mission. I hope that when we reach Cardassia, we find Colonel Kira alive and well.
So do I, Commander. So do I.
Captain on the Bridge.
All right people, what do you say we end this war?
Sounds good to me.
Ensign, I believe you know the way to Cardassia.
If I get lost, I'll just follow the ship in front of us.
The Federation invasion fleet has left Deep Space Nine. It will reach the Cardassian border by tomorrow night.
Our brave Jem'Hadar soldiers have a motto. Victory is Life.

I'm glad you're familiar with it. Because today, those words have meaning for us all. The outcome of this battle will determine the outcome of the war. Either we destroy their invasion forces or they destroy us. There is no other option.
Fight well today, and Romulus will be yours to do with as you wish.
Yes, yes and Earth too.
I assure you, the pleasure is all mine.
Is something bothering you?
Apparently, I was under the mistaken impression that all Federation territories would fall under my jurisdiction, including Earth.
And so they shall.
But you promised the Breen.
I would promise the Breen the entire Alpha Quadrant if I thought it would help win this war.
The Founder is wise in all things.
Founder. I've heard a disturbing rumor about the traitor Damar.
What about him?
He may be alive.
Is this possible?
I don't see how. We destroyed his ship, his rebel bases.
But his body was never found.
They say he's here on Cardassia Prime. In the capital, no less.
Look into this matter.
If Damar is alive
He won't be for long.
Halt. Step forward. Slowly.
I'm sorry, have we done something wrong? We're new to the city and I'm afraid we're lost.
Quiet! You are Legate Damar.
I told you you looked like him. I can't tell you how many times my cousin has been mistaken for that traitor.
He will be taken to Dominion Headquarters. You will die here.
I do not understand you.
I don't mean to sound ungrateful, but what are you doing here?
Watching your backs.
I thought we decided it would be safer if you stayed out of sight.
That's what the helmet's for. You should be wearing one too. Every Jem'Hadar and Breen soldier on Cardassia is looking for you.
If I'm going to lead this revolt, I can't do it hiding in a cellar. It was necessary for me to attend the gathering tonight.
Well, fill me in later. If anyone stops us, you're my prisoners.
But the vote was unanimous. The work disruptions begin tomorrow.
Power, communication and transportation facilities throughout Cardassia will be sabotaged.
The Dominion fleet will be cut off from all ground support.
That way, they'll have to face the invasion force on their own.
And once the Dominion is crushed

All Cardassia will be free again. Oh, when you were a small boy, I was worried about you. Always getting in trouble. So secretive, so full of deceit. Who would have thought those distasteful characteristics would be turned to virtues. More tea?
You're too kind.
Do you hear that, Chief?
Sounds like the Doppler compensators are out of phase.
Ensign, how's she handling?
She's not quite as smooth as the old Defiant, sir. Feels a bit sluggish.
Chief?
I'm on it. O'Brien to Engineering.
Engineering.
Recalibrate the inertial dampers and check the plasma flow regulators while you're at it.
Right away, Chief.
You'd think someone would have come up with a better inertial control system.
What's that, Miles?
I said I wish you'd wipe that grin off your face. You're not the first person to fall in love, you know.
I thought you'd be happy for me.
I am happy for you. O'Brien to Engineering.
Engineering.
Now try re-aligning the induction coils.
Will do.
You're sure you're not angry?
Why should I be angry? I have been asking you to tell the doctor how you feel about him for the past month.
Well, now that he knows how I feel.
I am happy for you.
That's a relief.
But I am going to kill him.
You're kidding, right?
And Jadzia said I did not have a sense of humor.
Julian, there's something I need to talk to you about.
You're getting pressure from Keiko, aren't you?
How did you know?
It's a big decision. I'm surprised it didn't come up sooner.
Actually, we've been talking about it for quite a while.
Well, you can stop talking about it. We'll move the Alamo into my quarters.
I could still use a little more equalization on the torque buffers.
Right. I'll try to compensate with the impulse response filters.
That way, your quarters won't be so cluttered and you can still use it whenever you want.
I wasn't talking about the Alamo model. Besides, it's too big for your quarters.
You let me worry about that. So, what were you talking about?
Oh, it's nothing that can't wait. Is that any better, Nog?
Torque buffers are stable.
I wish she were here, too, Constable.
If we only knew where Kira was. If we could only be sure that she was all right.
The Colonel's a survivor.
This war, Captain. It has to end.
And it will. Soon. One way or the other.
Mother?
The Emissary's task is nearing completion.
Are you talking about the war?
You have walked the path the Prophets laid out for you, Benjamin. Do not falter now.
I don't intend to.
Know this, my son. Your journey's end lies not before you, but behind you.
Captain? Captain?
The Prophets came to me in a vision
I take it they weren't bringing good news.
I'm not sure. Only time will tell.
Hello, Adami.
You're back.
Is that all you have to say to me?
I see the Pah wraiths have restored your sight.
Yes, they've forgiven me. I was hoping you could find it in your heart to do the same.
I don't forgive war criminals. To think I took Gul Dukat to my bed. One of the most hated men in Bajoran history.
I've told you how much I regret my actions during the occupation.
Of course you do.
Have you learned how to release the Pah wraiths?
The secrets of the Kosst Amojan have been revealed to me, yes.
Then why haven't you gone to the Fire Caves and freed them?
I was waiting for you.
Then you do forgive me.
I need your help, Dukat. It's as simple as that.
All you have to do is ask. Together we will release the Pah wraiths so they can lay claim to the Celestial Temple and destroy the Prophets.
And their Emissary.
No, no, no. Benjamin Sisko will be dealt with by me and me alone.
Assuming he survives the invasion of Cardassia.
Oh, he'll survive. But I promise you, he'll wish he hadn't.
You going to sit there all night, Quark?
Got any threes?
Go fish.
Don't tell me you're quitting?
It's just not my game.
Want to try pinochle again? How about rummy, or gin rummy? Five card stud? Canasta?
How about some tongo?
Did they play tongo in Las Vegas in nineteen sixty two?
How could they? It's a Ferengi game.
Which is why my holographic program can't create it.
I know, I know, this place is period specific. For a hologram, you're not very accommodating.
Oh, is that why you dropped by? To insult me?
I dropped by because I had nothing else to do. My bar hasn't had half a dozen customers all day. Everyone's off fighting this stupid war.
It's not easy staying behind, is it? Knowing that your friends are out there risking their lives.
They think they have it rough? They should try leading my life for a day. The hospitality industry isn't for the faint-hearted.
A bartender's life is a lonely one.

That's true, but few people understand that. They think it's one big, happy party. They forget that the person giving the party never has any fun. He's too busy making sure everybody else is having fun. All I do all day long is give, give, give.
Bartending is a very noble profession. You do it well, under some very difficult circumstances, I might add. You should be proud.
You think so?
I know so, pallie.
I just hope Nog and the rest of those heroic idiots come back in one piece.
There you are. Vic, sweetie, are you ready? Jimmy and Peter are about to go on.
Sorry, pallie, got to run. Durante and Lawford are at the Sands. Can't miss that.
I thought you said a bartender's life was a lonely one?
It is. But I'm not a bartender.
Go fish.
Is it really necessary to rest so often?
You don't need to wait for me. Go on ahead. Wander aimlessly through these caves for the rest of your miserable life.
I'm in no hurry. During the occupation, my people found the Bajorans' fear of these caves amusing. And yet we never took the time to visit them. And now, here I am. It's ironic, isn't it?
I don't care.
Excuse me? I just meant
I'm sure you have many interesting anecdotes about the occupation, but I don't have any desire to hear them.
I meant no disrespect, Adami.
And stop calling me Adami. That privilege is no longer yours.
How should I address you then?
From now on, you will address me as Eminence. Is that clear?
Perfectly. Eminence.
I see your point. But for two millennia the Jem'Hadar have been the Dominion's first line of defense. It would damage their morale to have to take a back seat to the Breen.
Very well. In the spirit of our new alliance, I will inform the Jem'Hadar that the Breen forces will stand alongside them.
I'm glad that pleases you.
I think we have a problem.
Our lines are spread too thin, especially here, at the center. We need to despatch reinforcements immediately.
Do you agree?
Notify the Jem'Hadar. Order them to reinforce the center of their lines.
Now what?
Emergency power engaged.
Founder, I'm relieved to see that you're all right.
Long range communications are down. I can't contact the Jem'Hadar.
Of course I'll keep trying.
What caused the power failure?
I'm afraid it was sabotage.
Almost every Dominion installlation on Cardassia Prime has suffered damage.
Damar.
We captured some of the terrorists, but they're not soldiers. They're ordinary citizens.
Are you telling me the Cardassian people are rising up against us?
I'm sure it's only a small number of malcontents.
But we have no way of knowing that, do we?
Founder, may I make a suggestion?
Yes, I am sure that Broca would be very happy to hear what you have to say.
If the Cardassian people are responsible for these acts of terrorism, if Damar and his fanatics have turned them against us, then it's the people who should be punished.
Now what do you say to that?
Severely punished.
Well I'm glad we all agree. See to it.
It's been twenty four minutes.
Not bad.
If the Dominion hasn't been able to restore power to the capital, then the entire planet must be in chaos.
I hope so.
I'm afraid I was only able to find two more lightsticks. There's more about the house somewhere but I just couldn't
Just stop dawdling and give them to me.
How well I remember that tone of voice. It reminds me of the demanding and inconsiderate boy you used to be.
I haven't changed much, have I?
This will send a clear message to the Dominion. The Cardassian people will fight to regain their freedom.
I hope they realize their fight is just beginning. We're going to have to hit the enemy again and harder this time.
That won't be easy. They will have tightened their security.
That doesn't matter. We can't lose our momentum.
The Commander is right. We cannot rest until Cardassia's free. And when it is, we'll have you to thank for it. Without you, this rebellion would have died in its infancy.
Ironic, isn't it? The savior of Cardassia a former Bajoran terrorist.
Don't canonize me just yet.
It's been twenty six and a half minutes. Let's see what the Dominion has to say for itself.
Citizens of Cardassia. This latest wave of vandalism directed against your Dominion allies must stop.
I wouldn't count on it.

We know these disgraceful acts of sabotage were carried out by a mere handful of extremists. But these radicals must come to realize that their disobedience will not be tolerated. That you, the Cardassian people, will suffer the consequences of their cowardly actions. Which is why I must inform you a few moments ago, Dominion troops reduced Lakarian City to ashes. There were no survivors. Two million men, women and children gone in a matter of moments. For each act of sabotage committed against the Dominion, another Cardassian city will be destroyed. I implore you not to let that happen. Let us return to the spirit of friendship and cooperation between our peoples, so that together, we can defeat our common enemies, the Federation, the Klingons, the Romulans and all the others that stand against us. Thank you.
I should've killed that Vorta jackal when I had the chance.
You want another one? We'll attack Dominion Headquarters.
Chop off a snake's head and the body will die.
Exactly. Damar, for the past two years you've practically lived in that building.
If you're asking me if I know a way in, the answer is no. Not without a valid security protocol.
We'll use force. We're going to need some kind of explosives.
I'll get right on it.
What you're proposing is suicide.
If you don't have anything positive to say, Mila.
All right, I'll prepare some food. Nobody should die on an empty stomach.
Sir, Chancellor Martok would like to speak to you and Admiral Ross.
Put them through.
Gentlemen, a magnificent victory lies before us.
I trust those are prophetic words, Chancellor.
They are. And I've not forgotten the promise I made to both of you.
That the three of us would share a bottle of bloodwine on Cardassia Prime.
A bottle? I brought a barrel of twenty three oh nine. There is no finer vintage.
Then I'll meet you two on Cardassia.
We'll see who gets there first.
The Chancellor makes victory sound easy.
He knows it won't be. Sisko to all hands. Prepare to engage the enemy.
I'll say one thing for the Breen. They know how to pilot their ships.
So do you, Ensign.
Stay with him.
I'm trying. He's slippery.
Mister Worf?
Unable to lock target.
We have two Jem'Hadar ships coming aft of us, bearing one three six mark four.
Evasive action, pattern Delta.
Hang on.
Well done, Ensign.
But I lost the Breen ship we were after.
I wouldn't be too worried about it. There are plenty more to choose from.
You've hardly touched your meal. No wonder you're not looking well.
I'm not looking well because I live in a cellar.
Well, so does Legate Damar.
And what about him?
Well, he's finished everything on his plate. Which explains why he is such a fine, handsome figure of a man.
I'm afraid I don't follow you.
I do. Mila, I believe you're falling in love.
Oh, I'm old enough to be his mother.
Nonsense.
Politicians.
Who could that be?
I'll go see.
May I help you?
What's taking her so long?
I don't know.
Mila!
Garak! Garak, get out of there!
I can't look away for a second.
Just fix the shoulder.
Careful!
Sit still or you'll end up with one arm shorter than the other.
You'd do anything to beat me at darts.
I haven't lost a game to you in months.
I'm going to miss our games, Julian.
What are you talking about? You're going to be fine
I'm leaving DS Nine, Julian. I'm moving back to Earth.
Why?
I've been offered a position at Starfleet Academy. Professor of Engineering.
When?
When the war's over.
Oh. I see.
Somebody has to teach you officers the difference between a warp matrix flux capacitor and a self sealing stembolt.
Of course.
Captain, Admiral Ross for you.
On screen.
The Romulan flagship's been destroyed. Their entire line is collapsing.
We'll try to help.
With what? Ben, we're losing too many ships. We've got to find a way to turn the Dominion's left flank.
It's too well protected, but their lines are spread pretty thin in the middle.
You help the Romulans. Martok and I'll hit the center.
On my way. Dax, have attack wings sixty four and sixty five follow us.
Aye, sir.
What's taking so long?
Our engineers have assured me that our long range communications will be restored momentarily.
But you have been saying that for hours. And meantime, there's no way of contacting our ships. No way of knowing how the battle is progressing.
Founder, our troops have captured the traitor Damar.
Finally, some good news.
And there's more. Colonel Kira and Garak have been apprehended with him.
Even better. Shall I have them brought here?
What for? Have them executed immediately.
With pleasure.
Understood. It will be done at once. On your feet.
Why?
We prefer our prisoners to be standing when they die.
Does anyone have any last words?
You may kill us, but Cardassia will never
Enough. Final words are not permitted.
How disappointing.
Ready weapons. On my mark.
That's for Lakarian City. Legate Damar, I pledge my life to free Cardassia from the Dominion.
With men like you on our side, how can we fail?
Jem'Hadar ship off the port bow.
Shields are down to sixty percent.
Miles, this is no good. I'm going to have to get you to Sickbay.
I'm kind of busy right now.
That's an order.
Look, Julian.
You heard him, Chief.
Yes, sir.
Another Jem'Hadar to port.
Transferring auxiliary power to port shields.
Dax, we need some support from our attack fighters.
Aye, sir.
Breen ship off the starboard aft.
Sir, most of our fighters are either destroyed or under attack themselves.
Ensign, get us out of here.
I'm trying, sir.
Sir, the Cardassians. They're attacking the other Dominion ships.
They've switched sides.
Yes!
The timing couldn't be better. Come about and head for the center of their lines. This is our chance to punch through.
Aye, sir.
Founder, our long range communications are back online.
It's about time.
I don't believe it.
What now?
The Cardassian fleet has turned against us.
Have our forces pull back and regroup at Cardassia Prime.
But we'll be totally surrounded.
There will be no more running.
We should have rid ourself of the Cardassians at the first sign of rebellion.
If I could talk to the rebels, get them to change their minds.
Perhaps you could reawaken their patriotic spirit?
Exactly.
On the other hand, they're just as likely to convince you to betray us.
Me, betray you? Never!
That's right. We are not going to give you that opportunity.
Wait! You're making a terrible mistake.
I don't think so.
But I've done everything you've asked! I tell you I'm loyal. I believe in the Dominion! No! Wait! No!
I won't miss him.
I want the Cardassians exterminated.
Which ones?
All of them. The entire population.
That will take some time.
Then I suggest that you begin at once.
Captain, the Dominion forces are retreating toward Cardassia Prime.
Sir, Admiral Ross and Chancellor Martok would like to talk to you.
On screen.
I never thought I'd say this, but thank god for the Cardassians.
As I predicted, the day is ours.
Not yet it isn't.
Ben, we've driven the Dominion back into Cardassia Prime. We can keep them bottled up there indefinitely.
What if they use this time to rebuild their fleet?
He's right. The Dominion has displayed an ability to build ships at an impressive rate. We should continue the attack.
At what cost? We've already lost a third of our fleet.
And we must see to it that those soldiers did not die in vain.
Admiral, with the Cardassians joining us, we have an opportunity to put an end to this war once and for all.
All right, gentlemen. We press on.
My friends, songs will be sung about this day.
All right, people. You heard the orders. Let's finish what we started.
Let me guess. We're here.
We've reached the end of one journey and stand ready to begin another. What's the matter, Dukat? You look disappointed.
Well, this may sound naive, but I was expecting to see fire. They are called the fire caves.
And with good reason.
Lano ka'la bo'shar lanu no'vala, pahrom carana mokado ba'jah. Ko'se nusso ma'kora kajani. Lano ka'la Kosst Amojan.
Is that better?
According to this map, it's a long way from the cargo door to the briefing room.
Well, that could be a problem if we get trapped in the corridor.
What the hell?
It's the Jem'Hadar. They're leveling the city building by building.
All right, we have to go now.
Once we get inside the complex, we stop at nothing until we capture the changeling.
Let it be done!
We're with you!
For Cardassia.
For Cardassia!
Garak.

All during the years of my exile I imagined what it would be like to come home. I even thought of living in this house again with Mila. But now she's dead, and this house is about to be reduced to a pile of rubble. My Cardassia's gone.
Then fight for a new Cardassia.
I have an even better reason, Commander. Revenge.
That works too.
Oh. I rid myself of the Prophets and shed a lifetime of hypocrisy.
I've never seen you look so radiant.
I feel like a young woman waiting for my lover to sweep me away.
Do you give yourself willingly to the Pah wraiths?
With all my heart.
Then call to them.
Bring me the book. Meek rak dorrah Pah wran Yelim cha ono Kosst Amojan shay ta hel ter rah no'vala de ram
Sisko to Bashir. Report.
Three dead, eight wounded, four of them critically.
Doctor, I need every able-bodied crewman at their post.
I won't keep anybody here a second longer than I have to, sir.
Put him over here, will you.
She did pretty well for a first date, don't you think, Captain?
I'd say she did fine, Ensign. Mister Worf?
Sir, phaser banks are fully charged, but we are down to forty five quantum torpedoes.
That'll have to do. How are you holding up, old man?
All things considered, I think I'd rather be on Risa.
Well, that makes two of us.
Have you seen these reports, Captain? The Dominion has begun destroying Cardassian cities. Millions of people are dying.
Captain, we're approaching the Dominion defense perimeter.
Well, let's see what they have waiting for us. On screen.
Now we know.
We have a problem.
Just one?
I'm afraid it's a rather large problem. The cargo door is made of neutronium.
Then the explosives we brought aren't even going to make a dent.
You see the problem.
What do we do?
I don't know, but I'm through hiding in basements. I fail to see what is so funny, Garak.
Isn't it obvious? Here we are, ready to storm the castle, willing to sacrifice our lives in a noble effort to slay the Dominion beast in its lair and we can't even get inside the gate.
Maybe we could go to the door and ask the Jem'Hadar to let us in.
Or just have them send the shape-shifter out to us.
As I said, we have a problem.
But I've come to depend on having you here at my side.
Your advice to the Dominion has proven invaluable
Very well. If you feel the situation on the front lines demands your presence, I will not stand in your way. Knowing that you'll be leading our troops into battle is very reassuring.
I still can't help but wonder.
Wonder what?
What's under that helmet?
A braver man than you. Though I do find the shrillness of his voice very tiresome.
Founder, what's wrong?
I'm dying, that's what's wrong.
Perhaps you should rest for a while. Revert to your natural state.
I haven't been able to change form in weeks. It's ironic, isn't it, that I should die as a Solid.
You're not going to die. You're a god.
My loyal Weyoun. The only solid I have ever trusted.
I live only to serve you.
And you have served me well. I don't mind dying. It's knowing that my entire race is dying of the same illness and there is nothing I can do about it.
I would give my life to save yours.
If only it were that simple.
What if I give myself up? Pretend to be your prisoner.
They'd kill you on sight.
And us along with you.
The cargo door.
You're making a terrible mistake. I'm not a traitor! Please, just let me speak to the Founder. No, wait!
No!
For Cardassia!
Fall back, fall back.
Keep
He's dead.
Remember his orders. We stop for nothing.
For Cardassia!
For Cardassia!
We have a security breach.
The guards will deal with it. Is there a problem?
The guards. There're only a handful left in the building. I sent the rest to help eradicate the Cardassians.
You two, get out there and see that no one gets through that door. You, stay here. In case they fail.

We'll launch a three pronged attack. The Romulans and our new Cardassian allies will engage the Jem'Hadar forces. The Klingons will target the Breen and the Federation will take on the orbital weapon platforms. Any questions?
When do we go?
As soon as everyone's in position.
It will be a glorious battle.
But a costly one. Estimates project our casualties to be as high as forty percent. There's no telling how much higher they'll go once we send in our ground forces.
The Dominion is beaten and they know it, but they're going to make us pay for every kilometer of the planet.
Yes, they will.
Let's get on with it.
Godspeed, everyone.
Qapla!
Founder, perhaps we should consider finding a safer location.
And just where would that be?
Well, Colonel Kira. What a pleasant surprise.
The pleasure's all mine.
The Federation fleet has surrounded the planet.
I want you to contact the Jem'Hadar and the Breen, and you order their ships to stand down.
And order their troops on Cardassia to do the same.
I will do no such thing.
Tell me, where's my old friend Damar?
Damar's dead.
What a pity.
He died trying to free Cardassia.
What's left of it.
I wish you hadn't done that. That was Weyoun's last clone.
I was hoping you'd say that.
This war's over. You lost.
Have I? I think you'll find that neither the Jem'Hadar or the Breen will agree with that assessment. They will fight to the last man.
And what will that accomplish?
Isn't it obvious? You may win this war, Commander, but I promise you, when it is over, you will have lost so many ships, so many lives, that your victory will taste as bitter as defeat.
We're glad to find you in one piece, Commander.
Very glad.
What's your status?
Only three of us made it to the briefing room.
What about Damar?
He's dead.
Is your position secure?
I don't think the Jem'Hadar will attack. They won't risk endangering the Founder. She's in pretty bad shape. She just sits at her desk, deteriorating.
If she dies before ordering the Jem'Hadar to surrender
Then they will fight to the last man.
Captain, I should beam down there. The Founder will speak to me. I can reason with her.
You haven't had much success with her in the past.
It's worth a try. Think of the lives it could save.
Very well. Commander, tell the Founder that Odo is going to pay her a visit.
Tarna pur ono ull kess pah ran. Lano ka'la bo'shar lanu.
After you.
I'm honored.
Now you.
Why?
The Pah wraiths demand a sacrifice. Someone worthy of them. Who better than you?
No!
I offer you this life as nourishment to feed your hunger, to fuel the fires that will set you free. Kosst Amojan, I am yours now and forever.
Nerys.
It's been a while.
Yes.
Watch yourself. I don't trust her.
But you trust me.
Of course.
That's all I need to know.
Constable.
Garak.
You're looking well, Odo.
Thank you for seeing me.

It's always good to see you. But I have no intention of surrendering my forces. It would be a sign of weakness on my part. An invitation to the solids to cross into the Gamma Quadrant and destroy the Great Link.
Believe me, I'm well aware that the Federation has its flaws, but a desire for conquest isn't one of them.
And what of the Klingons and the Romulans? Can you make that claim for them too?
The Klingon and Romulan Empires are in no shape to wage a war against anyone. Besides, the Federation wouldn't allow it.
The Dominion has spent the last two years trying to destroy the Federation, and now you're asking me to put our fate in their hands?
Yes.
I can't do that, Odo. I don't have your faith in the solids.
Perhaps I can change your mind. Link with me.
Odo, what are you doing?
I'm afraid I can't Link with you, Odo. My disease prevents me from changing form.
If we Link, I believe I can cure you.
That's a very bad idea, Constable.
I agree.
Nerys, I know what I'm doing. Please, take my hand.
And if you cure me, what will you ask in return?
All I ask is that you Link with me.
I'm warning you, Odo.
Nerys.
Garak, put down your weapon.
I don't think so.
I said, put it down.
Move aside, Odo.
That won't be necessary. Will it?
If you will stand aside, I'll order the Jem'Hadar to cease fire.
I suggest we secure her in a containment field.
Don't worry, Garak. She won't try to escape. She's agreed to stand trial and accept responsibility for what she's done.
I would have thought she'd insist on going back to the Gamma Quadrant to cure her people.
There's no need for that. I'm going in her place.
For how long?
Nerys, it's time I rejoined the Great Link.
This is a moment worth savoring. To victory, hard fought and well earned.
What's wrong?
Suddenly I'm not thirsty.
Neither am I.
Before you waste too many tears, remember, these are Cardassians lying dead at your feet. Bajorans would call this poetic justice.
That doesn't mean I have to drink a toast over their bodies.
Humans. Pah. Ka DiJaQ.
Eight hundred million dead.
And casualty reports still coming in. Well, aren't you going to congratulate me, Doctor? My exile is now officially over. I've returned home. Or rather, to what's left of it.
Listen, I know that this must seem bleak

Some may say that we've gotten just what we deserved. After all, we're not entirely innocent, are we? And I'm not just speaking of the Bajoran occupation. No, our whole history is one of arrogant aggression. We've collaborated with the Dominion, betrayed the entire Alpha Quadrant. Oh, no, no. There's no doubt about it. We're guilty as charged.
You and I both know that the Cardassians are a strong people. They'll survive. Cardassia will survive.

Please, Doctor. Spare me your insufferable Federation optimism. Of course it will survive, but as not the Cardassia I knew. We had a rich and ancient culture. Our literature, music, art were second to none. And now, so much of it is lost. So many of our best people, our most gifted minds.
I'm sorry, Garak. I didn't mean
Oh, it's quite all right, Doctor. You've been such a good friend. I'm going to miss our lunches together.
I'm sure we'll see each other again.
I'd like to think so, but one can never say. We live in uncertain times.
The war between the Dominion and the Federation Alliance is now over.

Four hundred years ago, a victorious general spoke the following words at the end of another costly war. Today the guns are silent. A great tragedy has ended. We have known the bitterness of defeat and the exultation of triumph. From both we have learned there can be no going back. We must go forward to preserve in peace what we've won in war.
It's up to you now, Odo.
You're coming to Vic's tonight, right?
I will be there, but I will not dance.
Who's asking?
Commander Worf.
Captain.
Can you spare a moment?
Yes, sir.
We've been diskussing your plans for the future.
I was not aware I had any plans.
Commander, how would you feel about being named Federation Ambassador to Kronos?
I am not a diplomat.
And I am not a politician. But sometimes fate plays cruel tricks on us, Worf. Come. Kronos needs you. And what's more, I need you.
You helped him become Chancellor. You can't very well turn your back on him now.
Well my first loyalty is to you, Captain.
Thank you, Mister Worf. I'll probably regret this in the morning, but if it's what you want, then by all means.
It has been a great honor serving with you, sir.
The honor is mine.
I accept.
Excellent. An Ambassador who'll go targ hunting with me. Well, perhaps being Chancellor won't be so bad after all.
Congratulations, Worf.
When will you be going?
Soon.
You could come back, you know, once you've cured your people.
I could.
But you're not going to do that.

Nerys. You know my feelings for you will never change, but I have to do this. My people need me. They need to know what I know, to learn what I've learned from living among solids. It's the only way they'll ever learn to trust you.
You don't have to justify your decision, Odo. There's just one thing.
Anything.
I'd like to take you back to your homeworld.
I'd like that. I'd like that very much.
Hey, pallie. If you're here for another game of 'go fish,' I'm a little busy right now.
Actually, I'm here for the end of the war goodbye to Chief O'Brien goodbye to Odo goodbye to Worf party.
At the bar.
No, seriously, Miles, I envy you. Going back to Earth, a chance to enjoy paradise again.
Any idea where you're going to live?
No. Keiko and I are still mulling over a few possibilities.
Have you ever considered Minsk?
I don't think that's on our list.
New Orleans is a gorgeous city.
I've heard great things about Paris.
Minsk.
Jadzia loved Rio.
You've certainly got a lot of choices.
Yeah. Too many.
Minsk.
Wherever you decide to go, I'm sure that you and Keiko will be very happy.
Listen, Julian, I know Earth isn't exactly around the corner, but I still expect you to visit.
I intend to.
Yeah, you and me taking a little trip to Texas.
Standing side by side in front of the Alamo.
The real Alamo. You see? It's going to be great.
Absolutely.
I don't see how great it would be. Earth's nothing more than a rotating ball of boredom. If you ask me, you'd be better off staying here. And that goes for you and Worf as well.
Don't tell me you're getting sentimental, Quark.
Me? Not a chance. I just don't like change.

You'd better get used to it. Things are going to be pretty different around here now. To the best crew any captain ever had. This may be the last time we're all together, but no matter what the future holds, no matter how far we travel, a part of us, a very important part, will always remain here on Deep Space Nine.
Hear, hear.
Cheers.
Ladies and gentlemen. Tonight is a very special night for some friends of mine. They've been together a long time. But like the man said, nothing lasts forever. So, gang, this one's from the heart.
Dorra tolka bre tri pah wran. Kosst Amojan, come to me! I await you.
No!
Ben, what's wrong?
I understand now.
Understand what?
What I have to do. What I was meant to do. Kasidy, I have to go.
Go where?
To Bajor. To the fire caves.
I'll go with you.
No, I have to do this alone.

Did you really think the Pah wraiths would choose you to be their Emissary? Soon the Pah wraiths will burn across Bajor, the Celestial Temple, the Alpha Quadrant. Can you picture it? A entire universe set in flames, to burn for all eternity. The Prophets have sent me a gift. Their beloved Emissary, sent forth like an avenging angel to slay the demon.
I should have known the demon would be you.
Go on. Kill me if you can.
You'll have to do better than that, Captain.
This is too easy. That's it. Come closer. That's it.
Now bow to me. I said bow.
You are pathetic.
Then why are you the one on your knees?
First the Dominion, now the Pah wraith. You have a talent for picking the losing side.

Benjamin, please. We've known each other too long. And since this is the last time we will ever be together, let's try to speak honestly. We've both had victories and our defeats. Now it's time to resolve our differences and face the ultimate truth. I've won, Benjamin. You've lost.
The Pah wraith will never conquer anything. Not Bajor. Not the Celestial Temple. And certainly not the Alpha Quadrant.
And who's going to stop us?
I am.
You can't even stand up.
Then I'll stop you.
Are you still here?
Emissary, the book!
Farewell, Adami.
Sarah? Are you here? What happened?
The Emissary has completed his task.
But the Pah wraiths.
You've returned them to their prison within the fire caves.
The book was the key, wasn't it?
To a door that can never be opened again.
And Dukat? Is he dead?
He's where he belongs, with the Pah wraiths. Your time of trial has ended. You need to rest now.
I intend to. As soon as I return to Deep Space Nine.
That won't be necessary. You're with us now.
We found the Captain's runabout orbiting Bajor.
But when we scanned the fire caves, there was no sign of him.
Tarkalian tea. Soothing.
Better keep it coming.
You're not calling off the search yet, are you?
Not until we find your father.
What about the Kendra Province, where he bought that land. Maybe he went there for some reason.
Colonel Kira and Chief O'Brien have completed another scan of the planet. As far as they can tell, he is not there.
Something's happened to Ben. Something bad. I can feel it. The Prophets warned us.
Hello? Is anyone here? Ben? Is that you?
Kasidy.
Oh, Ben! I've been so worried about you. Where are we?
The Celestial Temple.
This is scaring me. Let's go home.
I can't. Not now.
Why not? Oh, God. This is it, isn't it? The sorrow that the Prophets warned us about.
It's difficult to explain. It's not linear.
What isn't?
My life, my destiny. The Prophets saved me, Kasidy. I'm their Emissary and they still have a great deal for me to do. But first, there is much to learn. Things only the Prophets can teach me.
When will you be back?
It's hard to say. Maybe a year, maybe yesterday. But I will be back.
And I will be waiting.
Kas, can you hear me? You seemed pretty far away for a second.
I was talking to your father.

(Jake takes a model chair from the house that Sisko built, and remembers when his dad told him they were going to DS9, the hugs, the laughter, the solar-
wind powered spaceship.)
You sure you want to leave without saying goodbye?
I'm sure. I've never been good at goodbyes.
There are going to be a lot of people that are disappointed.
If they don't know how I feel about them now, a few parting words won't make the difference.
Ah ha! I knew it! When I saw the two of you slip out, I said to myself, that no good, misanthropic, cantankerous, changeling is trying to sneak off the station without anyone noticing.
That was the idea.
Well, it's not going to happen.
Apparently not.
So, now that I'm here, is there something you want to say to me?
Such as?
Such as, 'Goodbye, you certainly were a worthy adversary.' Or maybe something with the words mutual respect in it.
No.
No? What do you mean no?
I mean no. I have nothing I want to say to you.
You're telling me that after all these years, after all we've been through, you're not even going to say goodbye to me?
That's right. Nerys, I'll be on the runabout. Huh.
Don't take it hard, Quark.
Hard? What are you talking about? That man loves me. Couldn't you see? It was written all over his back.
The Link. It's so different.
They're dying.
You should go to them.
Nerys, please tell everyone I'll miss them.
Even Quark?
Even Quark. But most of all
I know.
Odo.
You always said I looked good in a tuxedo.
You do.
Then this is the way I want you to remember me.
I'll never forget you.
Goodbye, Nerys.
The duty roster, Colonel.
Nice work. Congratulations on your promotion, Lieutenant.
Thank you, sir. I guess putting me in for promotion was one of Captain Sisko's last official acts.
I'm sure he's very proud of you, Nog.
I'd like to think so, sir.
Now about the cargo inventories.
I'll get right on it.
You know, the thing of it is, the apoptosis is really just part of the normal cardiac renewal process. What do you think?
I think that after dinner tonight, we should go to Quark's, spend some time in a holosuite.
Oh. I'd like a trip to Vegas.
Actually, I was thinking about the Alamo.
We can't go there.
Why not?

Because that's what Miles and I did. But I do have a new program. The Battle of Thermopylae. Do you know it? Well, it's about a force of Spartans led by King Leonidas, who defend a mountain pass against a vast army of Persians.
What happens then?
For two days, the Spartans lead a heroic struggle.
Until they're wiped out.
Yes. How'd you know?
Lucky guess. I take it we'll be the Spartans?
Fighting to the last man.
Just like the Alamo.
Exactly.
Have you talked to a counselor about these annihilation fantasies?
Do you think I should?
I'll set up a session for you tomorrow.
What about tonight?
Tonight we defend the pass.
Don't worry, it's guaranteed to grow hair within a week. Though if you ask me, that dome of yours is hairy enough. Besides, hasn't there been enough change around here already?
Quark! You mind explaining this?
Oh. That's this week's betting pool.
You're taking bets on who's going to be the new Kai?
It's a wide open field. Just between you and me, the smart money is on Vedek Ungtae.
Well just between you and me, all bets are off.
What are you talking about?
As of this moment, betting pools of any kind are illegal on this station. I catch someone placing a bet, I put you in a holding cell for fifteen days. Is that clear?
Fifteen days! Can I bring my own pillow?
Quark.
It's clear. It's clear.
It better be.
It's like I said. The more things change, the more they stay the same.
